p: Some degree of thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and deranged hemostasis is virtually universal during the critical phase ( Biswas et al., 2012, Trung et al., 2012). Moderate-to-severe thrombocytopenia is common. The typical evolution of the thrombocytopenia is consistent with early marrow suppression of megakaryocytopoiesis, followed by increased peripheral destruction of platelets from the late febrile to the early convalescent phase of the disease probably mediated by the evolving immune response to the infection, During the febrile phase, there is also a reduction in the number of total leukocytes and neutrophils, together with a relative increase in lymphocyte numbers that often includes a high proportion of atypical lymphocytes ( Kalayanarooj et al., 1997, Khan et al., 2010).
